Literature Review: Ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) has emerged as a powerful analytical technique in the field of biomolecular analysis, offering enhanced separation and characterization capabilities when coupled with mass spectrometry (MS). Recent advancements in IMS technology have led to significant improvements in resolution, sensitivity, and multidimensional analysis, revolutionizing the study of complex biological systems. This literature review focuses on the application of next-generation ion mobility experiments in various areas of biomolecular research, including glycomics, lipidomics, peptidomics, and proteomics.One of the key developments in IMS technology is the introduction of high-resolution instruments. Gabelica et al. (2019) provided a comprehensive overview of the principles and applications of high-resolution IMS, highlighting its ability to separate isomers and conformers that are indistinguishable by MS alone. This enhanced resolving power has proven particularly valuable in the field of glycomics, where the structural complexity of carbohydrates poses significant analytical challenges. Hofmann and Pagel (2017) demonstrated the use of high-resolution IMS-MS for the separation and identification of isomeric glycans, revealing subtle structural differences that impact biological function.In the realm of lipidomics, next-generation IMS has enabled more detailed characterization of lipid species and their structural variants. Kyle et al. (2016) employed high-resolution IMS-MS to separate and identify lipid isomers in complex biological samples, providing insights into lipid metabolism and disease mechanisms. The ability to distinguish between closely related lipid species has opened new avenues for biomarker discovery and metabolic profiling.Multidimensional IMS techniques have further expanded the analytical capabilities of ion mobility experiments. Dodds and Baker (2019) reviewed various multidimensional IMS approaches, including IMS-IMS and IMS-MS/MS, highlighting their potential for improved separation and structural characterization of biomolecules. These techniques have proven particularly useful in peptidomics and proteomics studies, where the complexity of protein mixtures often exceeds the resolving power of traditional analytical methods.In the field of proteomics, next-generation IMS has enabled more comprehensive analysis of protein structure and dynamics. Lanucara et al. (2014) demonstrated the application of IMS-MS for studying protein conformations and interactions, providing valuable insights into protein folding and aggregation processes. The ability to separate and characterize different protein conformers has implications for understanding protein function and developing therapeutic interventions for protein-related diseases.The integration of IMS with other analytical techniques has further enhanced its utility in biomolecular research. May et al. (2015) explored the combination of IMS with liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry (LC-IMS-MS) for metabolomics applications, demonstrating improved coverage and confidence in metabolite identification. This multi-modal approach has become increasingly popular in various areas of biomolecular analysis, offering a more comprehensive view of complex biological systems.Recent innovations in IMS instrumentation have focused on improving both resolution and sensitivity. Ujma et al. (2016) introduced a novel cyclic ion mobility spectrometer that achieved unprecedented resolving power, enabling the separation of closely related biomolecules. This technology has shown promise in the analysis of complex mixtures, such as those encountered in proteomics and metabolomics studies.The application of machine learning and artificial intelligence to IMS data analysis has emerged as a promising approach for enhancing the depth of biomolecular analyses. Bauer et al. (2019) developed a machine learning-based method for predicting collision cross sections (CCS) of biomolecules, facilitating structural elucidation and improving the accuracy of molecular identification. This integration of computational approaches with experimental IMS data has the potential to revolutionize the field of structural biology and drug discovery.As the field of IMS continues to evolve, new applications and methodologies are constantly emerging. Paglia and Astarita (2017) reviewed the use of ion mobility in clinical applications, highlighting its potential for biomarker discovery and disease diagnosis. The ability to rapidly analyze complex biological samples with high sensitivity and specificity makes IMS an attractive tool for clinical research and personalized medicine.In conclusion, next-generation ion mobility experiments have significantly enhanced the depth of analyses in biomolecular research. The combination of high-resolution IMS, multidimensional techniques, and integration with other analytical methods has expanded our ability to separate, identify, and characterize complex biomolecules. As the technology continues to advance, we can expect further improvements in resolution, sensitivity, and data analysis capabilities, opening new avenues for discovery in the fields of glycomics, lipidomics, peptidomics, and proteomics. The future of biomolecular analysis looks promising, with ion mobility spectrometry playing a central role in unraveling the complexities of biological systems.
